concepts.name: Blueprint
concepts.scenario: Constructing a High-Speed Rail Station.
concepts.theory_application: Create a comprehensive, authoritative document that translates the abstract vision of the rail station into precise, actionable specifications that eliminate ambiguity for all execution teams.

variations.theory: Definition: The blueprint must be precise, unambiguous, and complete. Procedural Link: The action is to ensure the blueprint is precise, unambiguous, and complete enough that a team of strangers could build the system exactly as intended.
variations.specific_deliverable: A Technical Schematic detailing load-bearing tolerances and material stress limits for the platform foundation.
variations.rubric: Blueprint is precise, unambiguous, and complete.

variations.theory: Definition: Scrum requires 'commitment' from the entire team. Procedural Link: The action is to ensure the blueprint (Technical Spec - N25) must act as the source of truth for the entire execution team, reducing ambiguity.
variations.specific_deliverable: A Product Backlog acting as the single source of truth for the construction phases and deliverables.
variations.rubric: Acts as source of truth reducing ambiguity.

variations.theory: Definition: Toulmin's model requires a Claim to be supported by evidence. Procedural Link: The action is to ensure the blueprint (Outline) must dictate the linear flow of the written argument, ensuring logical progression.
variations.specific_deliverable: A Logical Argument Outline for the funding proposal, ensuring the economic benefits justify the displacement costs.
variations.rubric: Dictates linear flow for logical progression.

variations.theory: Definition: Alexander's patterns define reusable solutions and constraints. Procedural Link: The action is to ensure the blueprint (Storyboard/Maquette) must be the authoritative final specification used to guide the fabrication or construction team.
variations.specific_deliverable: A 3D Maquette serving as the visual authority for the station's aesthetic and spatial flow.

variations.theory: Definition: RRI requires defining 'red lines'—non-negotiable ethical boundaries. Procedural Link: The action is to ensure the blueprint must detail the governance structure and all decision-making flows, ensuring transparency.
variations.specific_deliverable: A Governance Flowchart detailing decision rights for community displacement and noise mitigation.
variations.rubric: Details governance structure and decision flows.

variations.theory: Definition: Facilitating the learning and transfer of Blueprint. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Create a comprehensive, authoritative document that translates the abstract vision of the rail station into precise, actionable specifications that eliminate ambiguity for all execution teams.
variations.specific_deliverable: Lesson Plan

variations.theory: Definition: The universal structural principle of Blueprint. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Create a comprehensive, authoritative document that translates the abstract vision of the rail station into precise, actionable specifications that eliminate ambiguity for all execution teams.
variations.specific_deliverable: System Map

concepts.name: Constraints
concepts.scenario: Developing a Low-Cost Medical Device for rural areas.
concepts.theory_application: Explicitly define the limitations, boundaries, and non-negotiable restrictions that will shape the development of the medical device to ensure it is viable in the target environment.

variations.theory: Definition: The scientific method requires intellectual honesty. Procedural Link: The action is to define non-negotiable limitations on the experiment (e.g., sample size, budget, time, control variables).
variations.specific_deliverable: A Control Variable List defining non-negotiable limits on temperature sensitivity and power consumption.

variations.theory: Definition: Scrum requires 'commitment' from the entire team. Procedural Link: The action is to define the fixed resources and schedule (e.g., fixed budget, fixed time) against which the variable scope is planned.
variations.specific_deliverable: A Resource Constraint Matrix fixing the budget at $50 per unit against variable feature scope.
variations.rubric: Defines fixed resources/schedule vs variable scope.

variations.theory: Definition: Toulmin's model requires a Claim to be supported by evidence. Procedural Link: The action is to define the boundaries of the research (e.g., historical period, specific texts, theoretical lens chosen).
variations.specific_deliverable: A Scope of Inquiry Statement limiting the demographic study to three specific rural districts.

variations.theory: Definition: Alexander's patterns define reusable solutions and constraints. Procedural Link: The action is to define the specific formal limits set by the artist or client (e.g., medium, color palette, dimensions). (N12)
variations.specific_deliverable: A Formal Constraint Spec limiting materials to locally sourced, recycled plastic.

variations.theory: Definition: RRI requires defining 'red lines'—non-negotiable ethical boundaries. Procedural Link: The action is to define the ethical 'red lines' or core principles that the project must not violate.
variations.specific_deliverable: An Ethical Red Line Document forbidding restrictive patents that would block local repair.
variations.rubric: Defines ethical 'red lines' not to violate.

variations.theory: Definition: Facilitating the learning and transfer of Constraints. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Explicitly define the limitations, boundaries, and non-negotiable restrictions that will shape the development of the medical device to ensure it is viable in the target environment.
variations.specific_deliverable: Lesson Plan

variations.theory: Definition: The universal structural principle of Constraints. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Explicitly define the limitations, boundaries, and non-negotiable restrictions that will shape the development of the medical device to ensure it is viable in the target environment.
variations.specific_deliverable: System Map

concepts.name: Definition of Done
concepts.scenario: Releasing a software update for a pacemaker.

variations.theory: Definition: The scientific method requires intellectual honesty. (N09)

variations.theory: Definition: Scrum requires 'commitment' from the entire team. Procedural Link: The action is to create a formal, shared checklist of quality criteria that a product increment must meet to be considered releasable (e.g., code reviewed, all tests pass, PO approved). variations.theory: Definition: Facilitating the learning and transfer of Definition of Done. concepts.name: Effortless Action
concepts.scenario: Streamlining a hospital emergency room.
concepts.theory_application: Design the system and workflow to align with natural forces and capacities, allowing complex operations to proceed with minimal friction and resistance (Strategic Alignment).

variations.theory: Definition: The scientific method requires intellectual honesty. Procedural Link: The action is to aim for the aspirational state where the methodology is so refined and the understanding so deep that execution appears fluid and natural (Strategic Alignment).
variations.specific_deliverable: A Triage Protocol that simplifies decision-making logic to reduce cognitive load on nurses.

variations.theory: Definition: Scrum requires 'commitment' from the entire team. Procedural Link: The action is to design a process flow (Kanban) that aligns with the system's natural capacity to enable sustained, low-friction effort.
variations.specific_deliverable: A Patient Flow Kanban matching intake rates to staff capacity to prevent bottlenecks.

variations.theory: Definition: Toulmin's model requires a Claim to be supported by evidence. Procedural Link: The action is to aim for the pursuit of prose or argumentation so clear and natural that the argument flows without distracting the reader.
variations.specific_deliverable: A Communication Script for nurses to explain wait times clearly, reducing patient friction.

variations.theory: Definition: Alexander's patterns define reusable solutions and constraints. Procedural Link: The action is to aim for the mastery of craft so complete that the final creation appears natural and spontaneous.
variations.specific_deliverable: A Spatial Layout Plan that guides patient movement intuitively without need for signage.

variations.theory: Definition: Strategic Alignment is the principle of effortless action in harmony with the natural flow. variations.specific_deliverable: A Cultural Alignment Strategy working *with* existing staff habits rather than imposing new rules.

variations.theory: Definition: Facilitating the learning and transfer of Effortless Action. concepts.theory_application: Categorize knowledge into Known Knowns, Known Unknowns, and Unknown Unknowns to select the appropriate management strategy.

variations.theory: Definition: The Rumsfeld Matrix categorizes risk. Procedural Link: The action is to list the 'Known Unknowns' (variables to measure) and design probes for 'Unknown Unknowns' (surprises).
variations.specific_deliverable: A Variable Classification Sheet.

variations.theory: Definition: Cynefin distinguishes between Complicated (Known Unknowns) and Complex (Unknown Unknowns). Procedural Link: The action is to separate the plan into 'Tasks' (Complicated) and 'Experiments' (Complex).
variations.specific_deliverable: A Cynefin Sorting Board.

variations.theory: Definition: Socratic Wisdom is knowing what you do not know. Procedural Link: The action is to explicitly list the limits of the archive and the silence in the historical record.

variations.theory: Definition: Negative Capability is the capacity to be in uncertainties. Procedural Link: The action is to mark the areas of the canvas that must remain undefined to allow for emergence.
variations.specific_deliverable: A Negative Space Map.

variations.theory: Definition: The Precautionary Principle applies when unknowns have ruinous potential. Procedural Link: The action is to identify the 'Ruin' scenarios (Unknown Unknowns) that require total avoidance.

concepts.name: Capacity
concepts.scenario: Planning a sprint with a reduced team.
concepts.theory_application: Assess the finite limits of time, energy, and resources available to ensure the plan is realistic and sustainable.

variations.theory: Definition: Theory of Constraints identifies the bottleneck. Procedural Link: The action is to identify the scarcest resource (e.g., centrifuge time) and subordinate the entire plan to that constraint.
variations.specific_deliverable: A Bottleneck Schedule.

variations.theory: Definition: Velocity is the empirical measure of capacity. Procedural Link: The action is to use yesterday's weather (historical velocity) to cap the scope of the next cycle.
variations.specific_deliverable: A Velocity Forecast.
variations.rubric: Uses historical velocity to cap scope.

variations.theory: Definition: Deep Work is a finite cognitive resource. Procedural Link: The action is to budget the project in terms of 'Deep Work Hours' rather than calendar days.
variations.specific_deliverable: A Deep Work Budget.

variations.theory: Definition: Creative stamina is a physical resource. Procedural Link: The action is to plan the work intensity to match the physical and emotional stamina of the performers.
variations.specific_deliverable: A Rehearsal Intensity Graph.

variations.theory: Definition: Carrying Capacity is the maximum population an environment can sustain. Procedural Link: The action is to assess the 'social carrying capacity' of the community to absorb change.
variations.specific_deliverable: A Community Bandwidth Assessment.
